articles.headline: Pricing Problem Suspends Nasdaq for Three Hours
articles.snippet: A problem at the Nasdaq stock market halted trading in all Nasdaq-listed stocks on Thursday. Nasdaq began reopening stocks for trading soon after 3 p.m.
articles.abstract: A problem at the Nasdaq stock market halted trading in all Nasdaq-listed stocks on Thursday. Nasdaq began reopening stocks for trading soon after 3 p.m.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:39 p.m. | The United States stock market showed again on Thursday that it remained vulnerable to technological breakdowns even as regulators and market operators work to keep up with trading that is increasingly electronic and driven by speed.

articles.headline: How BlackBerry Handled Past Wealth
articles.snippet: As the company’s fortunes spiral down, a look back shows little reward for loyal shareholders even in its heyday. But executives did well.
articles.abstract: As the company’s fortunes spiral down, a look back shows little reward for loyal shareholders even in its heyday. But executives did well.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started in an unlikely place, far from the headquarters of more established technology companies, and grew to become a dominant player. Along the way, investors piled in, undeterred by the company’s policy of never paying a dividend.

articles.headline: The Pentagon as Silicon Valley’s Incubator
articles.snippet: Government experts on computer vulnerabilities are heading to Silicon Valley to create technology start-ups specializing in tools aimed at thwarting online threats.
articles.abstract: Government experts on computer vulnerabilities are heading to Silicon Valley to create technology start-ups specializing in tools aimed at thwarting online threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the ranks of technology incubator programs, there is AngelPad here in San Francisco and Y Combinator about 40 miles south in Mountain View. And then there is the Pentagon.

articles.headline: American Tells of Odyssey as Prisoner of Syrian Rebels
articles.snippet: Matthew Schrier, a photographer, says he was held for seven months by jihadi fighters opposed to President Bashar al-Assad. After being robbed, tortured and accused of being an American spy, he escaped in July.
articles.abstract: Matthew Schrier, a photographer, says he was held for seven months by jihadi fighters opposed to President Bashar al-Assad. After being robbed, tortured and accused of being an American spy, he escaped in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matthew Schrier was helpless. An American photographer held in a rebel-controlled prison in the Syrian city of Aleppo, he and a fellow prisoner had been caught trying to gouge a hole in their cell’s wooden door. The captors took his cellmate, he said, beat him, and brought him back with blood-streaked ankles and feet.

articles.headline: Gingrich Will Be Back in the ‘Crossfire’ on CNN
articles.snippet: As a host of CNN’s revived “Crossfire,” Newt Gingrich will become a member of the news media that he once criticized. “And I hope to move it to the right,” he said.
articles.abstract: As a host of CNN’s revived “Crossfire,” Newt Gingrich will become a member of the news media that he once criticized. “And I hope to move it to the right,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — In defeat, the 2012 Republican presidential hopefuls have mostly faded from view, in ways that seem true to type. Mitt Romney is a contented grandfather. Rick Santorum leads a Christian movie company. Michele Bachmann is retiring from the House, although her pants-on-fire oratory is likely to find a new home.

articles.headline: In Markets’ Tuned-Up Machinery, Stubborn Ghosts Remain
articles.snippet: Today’s automated stock exchanges are fast and efficient, so long as the computers are working. When things go awry, chaos can emerge quickly.
articles.abstract: Today’s automated stock exchanges are fast and efficient, so long as the computers are working. When things go awry, chaos can emerge quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when the stock market crashed on Oct. 19, 1987, the Nasdaq stock market appeared to have done much better than the New York Stock Exchange. While the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23 percent that day, the Nasdaq composite index was off just 11 percent.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Acknowledges Area 51 Exists, but What About Those Little Green Men?
articles.snippet: Extraterrestrials’ big cultural moment may have come and gone, but for residents of a remote corner of Nevada, mysteries and conspiracy theories never go out of style.
articles.abstract: Extraterrestrials’ big cultural moment may have come and gone, but for residents of a remote corner of Nevada, mysteries and conspiracy theories never go out of style.
articles.lead_paragraph: RACHEL, Nev. — The Little A’Le’Inn has been an unlikely tourist destination in the Mojave Desert for nearly 25 years, selling souvenirs — from green alien coffee cups to E.T. Highway T-shirts — dedicated to the notion that we are not alone. Understandably.

articles.headline: Big Name Is Leaving Boies’s Firm After a Year
articles.snippet: David M. Bernick will move to the Dechert firm, a transition that reflects a developing era of free agency in the once-stable world of corporate law, where partners commonly switch firms, sometimes for millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: David M. Bernick will move to the Dechert firm, a transition that reflects a developing era of free agency in the once-stable world of corporate law, where partners commonly switch firms, sometimes for millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, when the renowned trial lawyer David Boies announced the hiring of David M. Bernick, general counsel at the tobacco giant Philip Morris, he called the move a “huge step” for his firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner.

articles.headline: Ballmer Exit Brings Microsoft a Chance for Reinvention
articles.snippet: Steven A. Ballmer’s departure paves the way for a generational change at Microsoft and gives it an opportunity to adapt to a world dominated by technologies that have eluded its influence.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Ballmer’s departure paves the way for a generational change at Microsoft and gives it an opportunity to adapt to a world dominated by technologies that have eluded its influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Steven A. Ballmer announced on Friday that he was leaving the top job at Microsoft, paving the way for a generational change at the once-dominant technology company and giving it an opportunity to reinvent itself for a world dominated by mobile devices, social media and other technologies that have eluded its influence.

articles.headline: Constant Acquisition at Microsoft, and One Deal That Didn’t Close
articles.snippet: By announcing his departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven Ballmer has signaled an impending end to one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the past two decades. But his record is as much notable for its misses as i...
articles.abstract: By announcing his departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven Ballmer has signaled an impending end to one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the past two decades. But his record is as much notable for its misses as its hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his impending departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer has put an expiration date on one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the last two decades.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: 50 Years After March, Views of Fitful Progress
articles.snippet: For Daniel R. Smith, 81, who attended the March on Washington in 1963, the country has a ways to go in realizing the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
articles.abstract: For Daniel R. Smith, 81, who attended the March on Washington in 1963, the country has a ways to go in realizing the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Daniel R. Smith was born dirt poor more than three-quarters of a century ago, there were only about 20 other blacks in his small Connecticut town. His own father had been born a slave in Virginia in 1862. Mr. Smith served as a medic in Korea in the years just after the Army had been desegregated.
